national_security_374: Special Counsel Robert Mueller has provided a list of questions to President Trump's legal team as part of the ongoing investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. Mueller's team has also suggested that they may subpoena Trump if he refuses to answer questions. Trump's legal team has compiled a list of 49 questions they believe Mueller may ask, including ones about Trump's knowledge of the Trump Tower meeting and his communications with Russian officials. The list of questions has been leaked to the media, prompting Trump to call the leak "disgraceful" and accuse Mueller of trying to "trap" him.
gun_control_and_gun_rights_176: President Obama is set to unveil a comprehensive plan to address gun violence on Wednesday, including executive actions and legislative proposals. The plan will include universal background checks, a ban on military-style assault weapons and high-capacity magazines, and increased funding for mental health services. The President will also call for stricter penalties for gun trafficking and more research on gun violence. The plan has drawn criticism from gun rights advocates, with one lawmaker threatening to impeach the President if he takes executive action. Despite this, the President remains committed to taking meaningful action to reduce gun violence in the wake of recent mass shootings.
gun_control_and_gun_rights_651: President Obama is expected to announce new gun control measures this week, following a task force led by Vice President Joe Biden that met with various groups, including the NRA and video game industry representatives. middle_east_450: The US is considering military action against Syria in response to a chemical weapons attack, despite the UK Parliament's rejection of military intervention. immigration_814: President Trump's administration has announced that it will resume accepting renewal requests for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, following a court order. politics_35: Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor and 2012 Republican presidential nominee, has criticized President Trump in an op-ed, saying he has not "risen to the mantle of the office" and has divided Americans and alienated allies. abortion_312: Missouri and Alabama have recently passed strict abortion laws, with Missouri banning abortions after eight weeks of pregnancy and Alabama banning abortions at any time, except in cases of medical emergency. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion nationwide in 1973.
gun_control_and_gun_rights_216: President Obama is set to unveil a comprehensive gun control plan, including a ban on assault weapons and high-capacity magazines, universal background checks, and new laws against gun trafficking. economy_and_jobs_228: The US unemployment rate dropped to 7.7% in November, with the economy adding 146,000 jobs, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The rate is the lowest since December 2008, but the decline was largely due to people leaving the labor force. Hurricane Sandy had little impact on the job market, and retail and healthcare industries saw significant gains. However, construction and manufacturing sectors saw declines, and the report suggests that many Americans have given up looking for work. The unemployment rate has gone down, but the number of unemployed people has remained the same, and the economy continues to face challenges.
immigration_469: House Republicans are considering immigration reform, with Speaker John Boehner releasing principles for a bill that would provide legal status for illegal immigrants but not a specific pathway to citizenship. However, conservatives are skeptical of the plan and Senate Republicans are unlikely to pass a comprehensive bill this year. Democrats and some Republicans have held private talks on the issue, but there are significant differences between the two chambers. Meanwhile, President Obama's administration is pushing for action on immigration reform.
china_164: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam has withdrawn an extradition bill that sparked months of protests, but protesters say it's too little, too late. The bill would have allowed China to extradite alleged offenders in Hong Kong for trial on the mainland, which lacks independent courts. Protesters have been demanding universal suffrage, an independent inquiry into the protests, and an end to the use of the term "riot" to describe the demonstrations. Despite Lam's concession, protesters vow to continue their demands, and the government has faced criticism for its handling of the crisis. The withdrawal of the bill has been seen as a challenge to the Communist Party's narrative of China as a victim of foreign interference.
elections_187: Hillary Clinton's campaign has accused Donald Trump and WikiLeaks of conspiring to undermine her presidential campaign by releasing damaging emails and using Moscow talking points. Trump has responded by calling for drug tests before the next debate, suggesting that Clinton may have taken performance-enhancing drugs. The Clinton campaign has denied these allegations and has cast doubt on the authenticity of the emails. Meanwhile, Trump has continued to attack Clinton's health, suggesting that she may have been "pumped up" on drugs during the last debate.
immigration_690: The Senate Judiciary Committee has passed the "Gang of Eight" immigration reform bill, which would provide a pathway to citizenship for 11 million undocumented immigrants and invest in border security measures. The bill passed with a bipartisan vote of 13-5 and will now move on to the full Senate for consideration. The bill's backers are hopeful that it will gain a solid majority in the Senate and be signed into law by President Obama. The bill has faced opposition from some conservative groups and lawmakers, who argue that it does not do enough to address border security and the issue of student visa overstays. impeachment_392: The House of Representatives has delivered articles of impeachment against President Donald Trump to the Senate, marking the beginning of the impeachment trial. House Democrats have released a trove of documents obtained from Lev Parnas, a close associate of Trump's personal lawyer Rudy Giuliani, which include a handwritten note mentioning asking Ukraine's president to investigate "the Biden case." The Senate has been sworn in for the impeachment trial, with Chief Justice John Roberts presiding, and the impeachment managers, led by Congressman Adam Schiff, will make their case for removing Trump from office. The trial is expected to begin on Tuesday, and the outcome is widely expected to be a acquittal, as it takes a supermajority of 7 senators to convict. A close associate of Giuliani, Lev Parnas, has provided new evidence that Trump was directly involved in the effort to pressure Ukraine to investigate Democratic rival Joe Biden.
federal_budget_449: Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew has warned that the US government will exhaust its borrowing authority on Thursday, October 17, and default on its debt if Congress does not raise the debt limit. The Senate Finance Committee held a hearing on the matter, where Lew testified that prioritizing payments to bondholders over other creditors is not a viable solution. He also emphasized that the consequences of a default would be catastrophic, including increased interest rates, slower economic growth, and falling business confidence. The International Monetary Fund has urged the US to take urgent action to address the budget impasse and avoid a default.
elections_727: The upcoming election is expected to be a close one, with Republicans hoping to gain control of the Senate and Democrats fighting to keep their majority. Key races to watch include those in Iowa, Colorado, and North Carolina, with the outcome potentially indicating a shift in the balance of power in Congress. Despite polls suggesting a Republican advantage, Democrats are performing well in some states won by President Obama in 2012, and the outcome is expected to be determined by turnout and the performance of candidates in tight races. world_23: President Obama attended the memorial service for Nelson Mandela in Johannesburg, where he shook hands with Cuban President Raul Castro, sparking controversy. The service was a tribute to Mandela's legacy of democracy and equality, and Obama's speech emphasized the importance of continuing his mission. Other news includes the death of Nelson Mandela, the handshake between Obama and Castro, and the controversy surrounding it.
politics_71: President Trump is facing allegations of obstruction of justice and witness intimidation after a memo written by former FBI Director James Comey revealed that Trump asked him to end the investigation into former national security adviser Michael Flynn. The White House disputes the memo's accuracy, but Comey's notes of the conversation have been deemed credible by law enforcement sources. The development has raised questions about Trump's motives in firing Comey and his potential ties to Russia. Democrats are calling for an independent commission to investigate the matter, and some Republicans are also expressing concerns about the allegations.
politics_703: President Trump attacked Democratic lawmakers and the FBI in a series of tweets, calling them "un-American" and "treasonous" for not applauding his State of the Union address. The White House is expected to release a classified document that Democrats say will rebut a contentious Republican memo alleging FBI bias against Trump.
justice_department_583: Attorney General Eric Holder is under fire for the Justice Department's investigations into leaks of classified information, including secret subpoenas or searches for phone records and other information of journalists involved in reports about leaked classified information. The cases involve the Associated Press and Fox News, and Holder has been accused of targeting journalists as potential criminals, which could chill investigative reporting and potentially violate First Amendment rights. Some Republicans have called for his resignation, and he is facing questions over his involvement in the investigations.
world_779: The US and EU have imposed new sanctions on Russia in response to its actions in Ukraine, targeting individuals and companies close to President Putin and the defense industry. The US and EU have coordinated their actions to present a unified front, but there is debate within the US government over the effectiveness of sanctions and how to shape them. Russia has described the sanctions as a "provocation" and a "Cold War" tactic, and has vowed to retaliate. justice_department_407: The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has been under fire for targeting conservative groups for extra scrutiny when they applied for tax-exempt status. An investigation by the Treasury Department's inspector general found that the IRS used inappropriate criteria to identify and scrutinize groups with "tea party" or "patriot" in their names. The report also found that the IRS delayed decisions on some conservative groups' applications for more than three years and asked for unnecessary information. The IRS has apologized for the targeting and has acknowledged that the scrutiny was unfair. Some lawmakers have called for a full investigation and for the IRS commissioner to resign.
national_security_839: President Trump revoked the security clearance of former CIA Director John Brennan, a vocal critic of the administration, citing his "erratic" statements about the Russia investigation. world_771: The recent kidnapping of hundreds of schoolgirls in Nigeria by the extremist group Boko Haram has sparked international outrage and calls for action. federal_budget_318: Defense Secretary Leon Panetta warned that automatic spending cuts will damage US national security, putting the military on a path towards a "hollow force." President Obama and lawmakers are trying to reach a deficit-reduction agreement to replace the automatic cuts, known as the sequester.
gun_control_and_gun_rights_648: The National Rifle Association (NRA) held its annual meeting in Houston, Texas, where leaders warned members of an impending "long war" against gun control advocates. us_senate_160: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid threatens to use the "nuclear option" to bypass filibusters for presidential appointments if Republicans do not agree to confirm seven nominees by Tuesday. supreme_court_220: Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh is facing allegations of sexual assault from Christine Blasey Ford, who has accused him of attacking her at a party when they were in high school. white_house_197: President Trump and his legal team have launched a counteroffensive against former FBI Director James Comey, accusing him of lying under oath and leaking private memos about their conversations. impeachment_573: The House of Representatives has impeached President Donald Trump, making him the third President in history to be impeached. The House voted 230-197 to charge Trump with abuse of power and 229-198 to charge him with obstruction of Congress. The impeachment will now move to the Senate for a trial, where Trump is expected to be acquitted. The impeachment has deepened divisions in Washington and around the country, and is likely to have long-lasting ramifications for Trump and his presidency.
north_korea_98: North Korea has intensified its threats of an imminent attack against South Korea, while the US and South Korea are watching for signs of a potential missile launch. national_security_556: Special Counsel Robert Mueller has accused former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort of lying to investigators and breaching his plea deal. middle_east_331: The Israeli military operation in Gaza has ended with a three-day humanitarian ceasefire, but the conflict may not be over yet. politics_745: Virginia's Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax faces calls for his resignation after two women accuse him of sexual assault. elections_511: In Florida, Republican Ron DeSantis, the nominee for governor, has been criticized for his comment that the state should "not monkey this up" by electing Democratic candidate Andrew Gillum, who is black. isis_417: President Obama has announced a new strategy to defeat ISIS, including airstrikes in Syria and Iraq, and the deployment of Special Operations forces. middle_east_351: The US Senate is preparing to vote on a resolution authorizing the use of military force in Syria, with a bipartisan agreement reached on a resolution that limits the authorization to 60 days and prohibits the use of ground troops. The House of Representatives is also expected to consider the resolution, with Speaker John Boehner backing the president's call for action. justice_department_219: Attorney General Eric Holder is facing scrutiny over the Justice Department's seizure of Associated Press phone records, with some calling for his resignation. elections_548: President Barack Obama has questioned Mitt Romney's role at Bain Capital, suggesting that Romney's claims about his experience as a businessman are not accurate. terrorism_499: The Boston Marathon bombing suspect, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, was captured alive on Friday night after a massive manhunt that shut down the city of Boston. elections_400: Senator Bernie Sanders is leading the Democratic presidential race after his victory in Nevada's caucuses, with a strong chance of winning the South Carolina primary and potentially the nomination. elections_120: Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign is focusing on framing the election as a referendum on Donald Trump, rather than making a positive argument for her own candidacy. nsa_332: Edward Snowden, a former CIA employee and NSA contractor, has leaked classified information about US surveillance programs to the media, revealing the government's secret collection of phone and internet data. elections_851: President Trump endorsed embattled Alabama Senate candidate Roy Moore despite sexual misconduct allegations against him. national_security_92: President Trump is set to address the United Nations General Assembly this week, where he is expected to take a tough stance on North Korea's nuclear threats. The US has also been preparing for a potential military response to North Korea's threats. israel_714: President Obama is visiting Israel to repair his relationship with Prime Minister Netanyahu and address various issues, including Iran's nuclear program and the ongoing conflict in Syria. The visit comes as tensions between Israel and Iran escalate, and as the region remains unstable due to the Syrian civil war and other factors. Obama aims to reassure Israel that the US has its back, while also exploring options for a peaceful resolution to the conflict with the Palestinians.
federal_budget_554: President Obama and congressional Republicans are at an impasse over automatic spending cuts set to take effect on March 1, with each side blaming the other for the looming sequester. Meanwhile, House Republicans are standing firm in their refusal to consider any tax increases, and the possibility of a fiscal crisis that could tank the economy and sideline the President's legislative priorities remains a concern. The sequester was the President's idea, but he is trying to pin the blame on Republicans.
nsa_266: The National Security Agency (NSA) has been accused of collecting millions of telephone records and tracking internet activity, sparking controversy and calls for greater transparency. elections_198: The Republican National Convention is set to begin in Tampa, Florida, with Ann Romney scheduled to speak on Tuesday evening. us_senate_682: Senator Al Franken (D-MN) resigned from the U.S. Senate on Thursday after multiple women accused him of sexual misconduct. national_security_81: The Mueller report has been released, and it reveals that President Trump attempted to obstruct the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. The report also details numerous instances of Trump trying to prevent investigators from carrying out their mandate. Despite this, Attorney General William Barr has decided not to prosecute Trump for obstruction. The report also details efforts by Russian military officials to hack into computers and steal documents from the Democratic National Committee and Hillary Clinton's campaign.
federal_budget_245: House Speaker John Boehner has been actively working towards bipartisanship and recently passed a compromise budget plan with a vote of 332-94. The plan aims to reduce the deficit and ease some sequester cuts, but has faced criticism from conservative groups who oppose the deal. supreme_court_821: The Supreme Court has ruled on Arizona's controversial immigration law, striking down key parts while upholding others. The decision has political implications for President Obama and Mitt Romney, with Obama hailing the decision as a victory for comprehensive immigration reform and Romney supporting aggressive state efforts to fight illegal immigration. fbi_395: President Trump fired former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe on Saturday, just two days before his retirement, after the Justice Department's Inspector General found he had lied about his involvement in a media disclosure. impeachment_415: The House of Representatives is considering additional articles of impeachment against President Trump, and is seeking testimony from former White House counsel Don McGahn as part of their investigation. immigration_675: The Trump administration has announced new rules to restrict asylum for migrants at the southern border, requiring them to first seek safe haven in a third country. disaster_269: President Trump has faced criticism for his response to the hurricane in Puerto Rico, with some calling for a temporary waiver of the Jones Act to allow foreign ships to deliver aid. Meanwhile, Puerto Rico's governor and mayor have praised the administration's efforts, while Democrats have criticized Trump's response as inadequate and his tweets as nasty. The military has deployed a limited number of troops and ships to the island, and the Department of Homeland Security has said there is no shortage of U.S.-flagged vessels to deliver aid.
us_house_518: House Speaker John Boehner has announced the creation of a select committee to investigate the 2012 Benghazi attacks, with Rep. Trey Gowdy as chairman. elections_68: The CNN/ORC Poll shows that Hillary Clinton leads Donald Trump in hypothetical general election match-ups, but her lead is narrower than it was in January. impeachment_846: The Senate is set to begin the impeachment trial of President Trump on January 21, after the House votes to send the articles of impeachment to the Senate on Wednesday. national_security_702: Special Counsel Robert Mueller did not find that the Trump campaign conspired with Russia, according to Attorney General William Barr's summary. state_department_784: The US and Russia have differed on how to address the ongoing conflict in Syria, with the US launching airstrikes against a Syrian airbase in response to a chemical attack and Russia condemning the move as a violation of international law. elections_585: Mitt Romney has been criticized for twisting the narrative of the recent attacks on U.S. missions in Libya and Egypt. justice_department_263: President Trump has been accused of interfering in the justice system after the Department of Justice (DOJ) reduced its sentencing recommendation for his longtime ally Roger Stone. us_senate_12: Senate Democrats are planning to filibuster the nomination of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court, setting up a showdown with Republicans who are threatening to use the "nuclear option" to eliminate the filibuster for Supreme Court nominations. national_defense_576: The recent killing of Iranian General Qassem Soleimani by the US has sparked a wave of reactions from Gulf Arab leaders, who are torn between their longstanding alliance with the US and their fear of Iranian retaliation. politics_86: The release of long-classified documents related to the assassination of President John F. immigration_644: President Trump's travel ban, which was previously blocked by courts, has been partially reinstated by the Supreme Court. white_house_205: President Trump and his legal team celebrated after Attorney General William Barr sent a summary of the key findings in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's Russia investigation to Congress, which found no evidence of conspiracy or coordination between the Trump campaign and Russia. elections_337: In the latest developments of the US presidential election, Donald Trump has emerged as the presumptive Republican nominee after his last rival, John Kasich, suspended his campaign. He has been hospitalized and is in serious condition, but has communicated with investigators and reportedly told them that his brother was the driving force behind the attack. Investigators are still trying to determine if anyone else was involved in the bombings. A Republican-led House committee has requested all information on Tsarnaev from the Obama administration, raising questions about the efficacy of federal counter-terrorism efforts.
trade_526: The White House and Senate Republicans are pushing for the passage of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade agreement, despite opposition from Democrats and labor unions. President Obama has been accused of misleading the public and suppressing dissenting voices, and the agreement has been criticized for its potential negative impact on American workers and the environment. The Senate has voted down a bill to fast-track the TPP, and Democrats have threatened to filibuster any further attempts to pass the agreement. The White House has responded by releasing a list of names of Democrats who attended a meeting on the TPP, and has accused them of playing politics with the issue.
middle_east_535: Egypt's military has ousted President Mohamed Morsi and placed him under house arrest, with reports of violence and arrests across the country. The Muslim Brotherhood, Morsi's political party, has called for protests and warned of unrest. The military has appealed for calm and pledged to allow peaceful protests. The ouster has sparked international concern, with the US urging all parties to exercise restraint and work towards a democratic transition. The Brotherhood has denounced the coup and recalled past military rule, while the US must nudge Egypt back towards democracy. The events have raised concerns about the future of democracy in Egypt and the region.
impeachment_540: The Senate has begun the impeachment trial of President Trump, with Republicans and Democrats at odds over the rules for the proceedings. The Senate voted along party lines to approve the rules, rejecting Democratic efforts to obtain evidence and ensure witnesses are heard. The trial began with a marathon session that stretched into early Wednesday morning, with heated exchanges between the rival legal teams. The resolution establishing the rules for the trial was passed in a party-line vote, with Republicans forcing through the resolution after a rancorous debate. The trial is expected to last several weeks, with each side having 24 hours over three days to present their cases.
immigration_501: The Senate has passed a comprehensive immigration reform bill with a 68-32 vote, marking a significant step forward for immigration reform. The bill provides a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants and enhances border security. The House is expected to take up the issue soon, with a bipartisan group of lawmakers working on a package of targeted bills. Senate Gang of Eight members, including Marco Rubio, have been instrumental in shaping the legislation. The bill faces opposition from House Republicans, who prefer a piecemeal approach to immigration reform.
economy_and_jobs_591: The US economy added only 69,000 jobs in May, according to the Labor Department, falling short of expectations and sending the unemployment rate up to 8.2%. Republicans quickly seized on the disappointing numbers to criticize President Obama's handling of the economy, while Democrats argued that the economy is still adding jobs, albeit slowly. The slowdown in hiring was seen across different industries and was attributed to factors such as the spike in global oil prices, the European debt crisis, and the looming possibility of a long-term debt deal stalemate in Washington. The news has implications for the upcoming presidential election, with Mitt Romney arguing that the Obama administration's policies have failed to achieve their goals and the president stressing that the US is still adding jobs, but not quickly enough.
supreme_court_185: Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation hearings have begun, with Democrats vowing to scrutinize his record and Republicans expressing confidence in his confirmation. The hearings have been disrupted by protesters and Democratic lawmakers, with some calling for a delay in the proceedings. Despite the chaos, Kavanaugh has maintained a neutral stance, promising to be an "umpire" and not a "pro-plaintiff or pro-defendant judge." The nomination is expected to be a bitterly partisan fight, with Republicans holding a narrow majority in the Senate.
impeachment_715: President Trump's impeachment trial continues in the Senate, with his lawyers defending him against charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. Former National Security Adviser John Bolton's unpublished book manuscript, which includes claims that Trump wanted to withhold aid to Ukraine until it investigated his political rivals, has cast a shadow over the trial. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell has reportedly been "angry" over the revelations and has pressed the White House for an explanation. Trump has denied Bolton's claims and accused him of trying to sell a book. The Senate is expected to acquit Trump, with Republicans holding a majority in the 100-seat chamber.
world_641: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Saudi Arabia's King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to discuss the disappearance of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Pompeo emphasized the importance of a thorough and transparent investigation and the Saudi leadership strongly denied any knowledge of Khashoggi's fate. President Trump suggested that "rogue killers" could be responsible for Khashoggi's disappearance and announced that he would be sending Secretary of State Mike Pompeo to Riyadh to meet with the Saudi King. Turkish officials have evidence that Khashoggi was killed and dismembered inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, but Saudi officials have denied any involvement. The US has asked Turkey for an audio recording of Khashoggi's death, which is believed to prove he was brutally tortured before his premeditated murder.
supreme_court_755: Supreme Court nominee Judge Brett Kavanaugh faces allegations of sexual assault from multiple women, including Dr. Christine Blasey Ford and Julie Swetnick. Kavanaugh denies all allegations and has called them "smears" and "grotesque and obvious character assassination." His confirmation hearings have been delayed due to the allegations, and he is set to testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday. Other news includes Senator Ted Cruz being driven out of a restaurant by protesters chanting "We believe survivors" and Mark Judge, a high school friend of Kavanaugh's, denying allegations brought against him by Swetnick.
fiscal_cliff_835: President Obama and Congressional Republicans are at odds over a plan to avoid the "fiscal cliff," with the White House proposing $1.6 trillion in tax increases and Republicans countering with $800 billion in tax increases. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner pushed back against Republican attacks, saying that there will be no agreement without an increase in tax rates for the top 2% of income earners. House Speaker John Boehner called the White House proposal "nonsense" and accused the administration of wasting three weeks on a "la-la-land offer." The GOP counteroffer included $800 billion in tax increases, but the White House and congressional Democrats said it is not enough revenue to begin negotiating.
immigration_39: President Trump is expected to declare a national emergency to fund his border wall, despite potential legal challenges and criticism from lawmakers. The move could create a political issue for his 2020 presidential campaign. Trump will hold a rally in El Paso, Texas, on Monday, where he will make the case for his border wall and address immigration and border security. The event will be attended by thousands of supporters and counter-protesters, with both sides addressing the issue of border security. The president's demand for $5.7 billion in funding for the wall has triggered a government shutdown and could lead to another one if a deal is not reached by Friday. Congressional negotiators have reached a tentative deal to avoid another shutdown, but it does not include the funding Trump wants for his wall.
great_britain_379: Former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, known as the "Iron Lady" for her uncompromising political style and conservative beliefs, passed away at the age of 87 after suffering a stroke. She was the first and only female Prime Minister of Britain and served from 1979 to 1990, transforming the country with her radical economic and social policies. Thatcher was a controversial figure, both admired and criticized for her unwavering dedication to free markets and her handling of the Falklands War and the miners' strike. She was a close ally of US President Ronald Reagan and together they helped end the Cold War. Thatcher's legacy is still debated, with some celebrating her as a hero and others criticizing her for her divisive policies and the negative impact on the working class.
elections_864: The third Democratic debate took place in Houston, with all major candidates on stage together for the first time. The debate highlighted deep divides among candidates on healthcare, with Joe Biden and Elizabeth Warren exchanging blows over their differing proposals. Bernie Sanders also defended his "Medicare for All" plan, while other candidates like Kamala Harris and Pete Buttigieg sought to regain momentum. The debate was notable for its lack of direct attacks on front-runners Biden and Warren, with most candidates focusing on their own policies and records. The race remains tight, with Biden leading in national polls and Warren and Sanders vying for the progressive alternative spot.
elections_410: Florida's secretary of state has ordered recounts in the U.S. Senate and governor races due to close margins. The governor race between Ron DeSantis and Andrew Gillum is heading for an automatic recount, while the Senate race between Rick Scott and Bill Nelson may be decided by a manual recount. The recounts have been marred by controversy and allegations of fraud, with President Trump weighing in on the process. Meanwhile, other high-profile elections in Georgia, Arizona, and elsewhere remain undecided due to legal challenges and ballot reviews. The outcome of these elections could have significant implications for the balance of power in Congress and the presidency.
immigration_112: President Obama has called for comprehensive immigration reform, including a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, improved border security, and reform of the legal immigration system. Eight senators have proposed a bipartisan framework for reform, which includes a probationary legal status for undocumented immigrants and a faster path to citizenship for young people brought to the country illegally and seasonal agriculture industry workers. The proposal also includes stricter border enforcement measures and new rules ensuring immigrants have left the country in compliance with their visas. President Obama is set to speak on the issue on Tuesday, and the proposal is expected to take precedence in Congress.
supreme_court_593: The confirmation hearing of Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh has been delayed due to an allegation of sexual assault made by Christine Blasey Ford. Ford has asked for an FBI investigation before testifying, but Republicans have rejected this and instead offered a private hearing. Democrats are calling for an FBI investigation and a delay in the vote, while Republicans are pushing for a swift confirmation. The similarities between the Kavanaugh and Thomas confirmations are noted, including the partisan divide and the involvement of Anita Hill.
elections_384: Bernie Sanders won three contests on Saturday, sweeping Washington, Alaska, and Hawaii's caucuses, but still trails Hillary Clinton in the delegate count. Sanders needs to win big in upcoming contests to catch up to Clinton's lead. Clinton has a 1,690-946 delegate advantage, and Sanders will need to win a majority of the remaining delegates to win the nomination. The next major contest is in Wisconsin on April 5.
fbi_272: The FBI has been ordered to investigate Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh after a contentious Senate hearing featuring Christine Blasey Ford, who accused Kavanaugh of sexual assault. The investigation is limited to one week and will explore allegations made by Ford and Deborah Ramirez. Kavanaugh denies all allegations. The FBI has reached out to Ramirez and Ford for interviews. President Trump expressed confidence in Kavanaugh and the investigative process. Sen. Jeff Flake (R-AZ) joined Democrats in calling for the investigation. The FBI's findings are expected to be given to the White House and the Senate.
elections_172: Democrats had a successful night in off-year elections on Tuesday, with wins in Kentucky and Virginia and gains in state legislatures. In Kentucky, Democrat Andy Beshear beat Republican Governor Matt Bevin, despite President Trump's efforts to support Bevin. The election was seen as a rejection of Trump and his policies, with Beshear performing well in urban and suburban areas. In Virginia, Democrats flipped both chambers of the state legislature, giving them full control of the state. The elections also highlighted the challenges facing Republicans in swing areas, as they try to balance support for Trump with the need to appeal to moderate voters.
elections_602: Donald Trump dominated Super Tuesday, winning seven out of fifteen Republican contests, and his rival, Ted Cruz, described the current state of the Republican Party as "fractured" and "at a crossroads." Trump's success has led to a drop-off in Democratic turnout, and the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) was notable for Trump's absence. The latest primaries and caucuses saw Cruz perform well, with Trump losing in Maine and Kansas. Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are competing in the Democratic race, with Clinton leading in delegates. The Republican race may come down to a two-candidate race between Trump and Cruz, while the Democratic race remains competitive.
elections_694: Bill Clinton delivered a powerful speech at the Democratic National Convention, defending President Obama and attacking the Republican Party. He highlighted the successes of his own presidency and contrasted them with the current state of the economy, which he argued has improved under Obama. Clinton also emphasized the importance of compromise and bipartisanship, and poked fun at the GOP's attempts to rebut Obama's policies. His speech was well-received by delegates and marked a strong endorsement of Obama's candidacy.
politics_693: President Trump's former lawyer, Michael Cohen, pleaded guilty to eight criminal charges, including campaign finance violations, and implicated Trump in the payments to silence two women who accused him of affairs. Trump denied any wrongdoing and called Cohen a "devious little rat." Cohen's lawyer, Lanny Davis, questioned Trump's loyalty to the United States and suggested that he was unfit to hold office. The news comes as Trump's former campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, was found guilty on eight charges of financial fraud. The developments increase political pressure on Trump ahead of November's congressional elections.
politics_508: President Trump and his former advisor Steve Bannon are at odds, with Bannon facing backlash from conservative strategists and losing financial support from Rebekah Mercer. Bannon had criticized Trump's family in a forthcoming book, and Trump responded with a cease-and-desist letter and a statement calling Bannon "lost" and "dangerous." Meanwhile, a new book by Michael Wolff reveals alleged inner secrets of the Trump White House, prompting a furious response from the president and lawyers sending a cease-and-desist letter to the publisher. The book contains controversial quotes from Bannon and other officials, and its accuracy has been questioned.
middle_east_824: The historic nuclear deal between Iran and six world powers has been met with both celebration and skepticism. The agreement, which temporarily halts Iran's nuclear program in exchange for sanctions relief, is seen as a significant step towards a more peaceful Middle East, but also raises concerns about Iran's intentions and the effectiveness of the deal. The deal has sparked debate in the US, with some hailing it as a significant achievement and others criticizing it as a reckless move that fails to address Iran's aggressive behavior in the region. The agreement will be put to the test in the coming months, as Iran is expected to comply with the terms of the deal and allow intrusive inspections of its nuclear facilities. The outcome will have significant implications for the future of the Middle East and the global fight against nuclear proliferation.
middle_east_495: On Tuesday, an attack on the US consulate in Benghazi, Libya killed four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens, and injured others. The attack was reportedly sparked by a protest over an anti-Islam film, but some officials believe it was a planned assault. President Obama condemned the attack and promised to bring the perpetrators to justice, while Libyan leaders also condemned the violence and apologized to the US. The attack has brought foreign policy to the forefront of the presidential campaign, with both Obama and Romney addressing the issue.
middle_east_283: President Obama faces a political dilemma as evidence mounts that the Syrian government has used chemical weapons, crossing the "red line" he set last year. Congressional Republicans are urging the President to take action, while Democrats are calling for a cautious approach. The White House is considering its options, including arming the opposition and establishing a safe zone. The use of chemical weapons in Syria brings back memories of the Iraq War and its controversial use of intelligence assessments. The President's credibility is at stake, and the situation is a "game changer" that could have significant implications for his legacy.
europe_273: Scotland has voted to remain part of the United Kingdom in a historic referendum, with 55% of voters rejecting independence and 45% supporting it. The outcome has been met with relief from world leaders, including US President Barack Obama and British Prime Minister David Cameron, who had both expressed their opposition to Scottish independence. The result has also sparked the resignation of Scotland's pro-independence leader, Alex Salmond. The vote has been described as a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" and a "day that everybody will remember.
elections_608: Carly Fiorina made a strong impression at the recent Republican debate, with many considering her a potential winner of the event. She addressed Donald Trump's previous comments about her appearance and proved herself a skilled debater. The debate also saw a focus on immigration and vaccinations, with Ben Carson and Marco Rubio delivering strong performances. The event marked a turning point for the GOP, with some candidates struggling to stand out while others solidified their positions. Overall, the debate highlighted the diversity of the Republican field and the ongoing competition for the nomination.
elections_333: Donald Trump has faced backlash for his comments towards the family of Humayun Khan, a fallen Muslim US Army captain. Trump's criticism has sparked outrage from veterans and members of his own party, with Senator John McCain calling for the nominee to set an example for the country. The controversy has reignited questions about Trump's fitness for office and his ability to unite the country. Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton has attacked Trump's tax plan and called for him to release his tax returns. Trump has responded by claiming that the Khans were silent during their son's DNC address because of their Muslim faith.
middle_east_567: The United States has announced that it will provide direct military aid to Syrian rebels, after determining that the Syrian government has used chemical weapons against them. The decision comes as no surprise, as President Obama had previously stated that the use of chemical weapons by the Syrian government would be a "red line" that would prompt greater US involvement in the conflict. The US will provide small arms and ammunition to the main rebel group, the Supreme Military Council, and is considering providing anti-tank weapons and establishing a no-fly zone. The decision has been met with mixed reactions, with some lawmakers calling for more intervention and others expressing concern about the risks of providing sophisticated weaponry to the rebels. The Syrian government has denied using chemical weapons and accused the US of producing a "statement full of lies." The conflict in Syria has killed over 90,000 people and shows no signs of progress towards a political solution.
elections_360: In the aftermath of the first presidential debate, Mitt Romney has gained ground in the polls, with a 47-45 lead over President Obama according to a Gallup poll. The debate has also had a positive impact on Romney's image, with a 46% margin of victory and a 72% to 20% margin of being declared the winner. Obama's performance has been criticized, with some saying he was too passive and failed to defend his record. The upcoming vice presidential debate between Joe Biden and Paul Ryan is highly anticipated, with both sides expecting a fierce contest.
national_security_462: Former FBI Director James Comey testified before the Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday, providing a detailed account of his interactions with President Trump. Comey stated that Trump had asked him to end the investigation into former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn, and that he had assured Trump on three separate occasions that he was not under investigation. Comey also described Trump as self-serving and dishonest, and criticized the White House's explanation for his firing. The testimony has raised questions about obstruction of justice and the Russia investigation, but Comey stated that he did not consider Trump's comments a directive to end the investigation.
media_bias_190: Facebook, the largest news distributor, has been accused of censoring conservative news from its trending topics module. A former news curator alleged that popular conservative topics were deliberately left out of the trending list. Facebook denies the allegation, but the report highlights concerns about the company's growing influence in shaping what news is read. The company relies on a small team of editors to determine what topics are trending, and there have been accusations of bias in the selection process. The issue raises questions about the role of technology in shaping our access to information and the potential for algorithms to reflect the biases of those who create them.
elections_522: Mitt Romney accepted the Republican presidential nomination, promising to lead America to a brighter future. Chris Christie delivered a keynote speech, emphasizing the need for strong leadership and criticizing President Obama. Paul Ryan gave a powerful speech, attacking Obama's policies and promising to solve the country's economic problems. Fact-checkers found some false claims in Ryan's speech, but he defended the Republicans against Medicare reform attacks. Romney's speech focused on his executive experience and values, offering solutions to the country's challenges. He drew contrasts with Obama but avoided anger, emphasizing the need for change.
politics_368: President Trump delivered an Oval Office address Tuesday night to make the case for his border wall, but did not offer any new solutions to end the partial government shutdown. He argued that a humanitarian crisis exists at the border and urged Democrats to fund his immigration proposal, but top congressional Democrats accused him of fearmongering and factual inaccuracies. The shutdown, now in its 19th day, has left hundreds of thousands of federal workers without pay and no clear end in sight. The President has threatened to declare a national emergency to bypass Congress, but Democrats have refused to budge on the issue.
us_senate_88: Mike Pompeo, President Trump's nominee for Secretary of State, faced a crucial vote in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Monday. Despite initial opposition from Senator Rand Paul, the committee voted in favor of Pompeo's nomination with a party-line vote. The vote was seen as a test of the President's ability to secure confirmation for his controversial nominees. Democrats have raised concerns about Pompeo's hawkish views and his past statements on issues such as same-sex marriage and Islam. However, the nomination is expected to pass in the full Senate this week, with at least three Democratic senators supporting him.
elections_192: Donald Trump is surging in the polls after Hillary Clinton's health scare and controversial comments about his supporters. Clinton was diagnosed with pneumonia and left a 9/11 memorial event early, leading to questions about her health and honesty. Trump has criticized Clinton's remarks and called for her to retract them, while also releasing more information about his own health. The incident has fueled speculation about Clinton's fitness for office and Trump's ability to win the election.
gun_control_and_gun_rights_414: In the wake of the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting, President Obama has pledged to take action to prevent similar tragedies in the future. The shooting has renewed calls for gun control, with some lawmakers promising to introduce new legislation. The president has avoided specifics, but has expressed a desire to take action. The shooting has also raised questions about the role of guns in society and the need for stricter gun control measures.
healthcare_391: Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius testified before Congress about the problems with the Affordable Care Act's website, apologizing for the issues and taking responsibility. Republicans are calling for her to be fired, while Democrats are defending her and the law. The website is experiencing technical issues and many Americans are receiving cancellation notices for their health insurance plans, despite President Obama's promise that they could keep their plans. The media is now paying more attention to the GOP's warnings about the law, which were previously dismissed.
immigration_328: President Obama announced a new policy that allows certain young undocumented immigrants to avoid deportation and receive work permits. The policy has been met with mixed reactions, with some praising the move as a step towards comprehensive immigration reform and others criticizing it as an overreach of executive power. Mitt Romney, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, has refused to say whether he would reverse the policy if elected, while some Republicans in Congress have vowed to sue to block the move. The policy has also sparked a heated debate about the role of immigration in the upcoming presidential election.
elections_62: According to recent polls, the presidential race between Barack Obama and Mitt Romney remains tight, with Obama leading in Florida, Ohio, and Wisconsin but with Romney gaining ground. The polls indicate that the race is largely driven by partisan divisions, with little change in support for either candidate since Romney chose Paul Ryan as his running mate. The candidates are neck and neck among independent voters, and the race is expected to remain close in the coming weeks.
immigration_14: The Trump administration has faced intense criticism for its "zero tolerance" policy on immigration, which has resulted in the separation of over 2,000 children from their parents at the US-Mexico border. The policy has been widely condemned by medical professionals, religious leaders, and immigration activists, who warn that the practice could cause lasting psychological trauma to the children. Despite pressure from lawmakers and advocacy groups, the administration has refused to back down, with President Trump signing an executive order to end the separation of families but maintaining the "zero tolerance" policy. The order has been criticized for not addressing the fate of already-separated children, and the administration's plan to hold families in detention facilities has raised concerns about the legality and humanity of the policy.
us_house_619: The impeachment inquiry into President Trump has heard testimony from two career diplomats, William Taylor and George Kent, who have provided detailed accounts of the President's efforts to pressure Ukraine to investigate his political rival, Joe Biden. Taylor testified that he had a member of his staff overhear a phone call between Trump and Gordon Sondland, in which Trump asked about the investigations and Sondland told him the Ukrainians were ready to proceed. Taylor also revealed that the $391 million in US security aid was withheld from Ukraine unless they cooperated. The hearing featured a dramatic moment when Trump tweeted insults at former Ambassador Marie Yovanovitch as she testified. The inquiry has highlighted a culture of corruption and intimidation within the Trump administration and has sparked a partisan divide in the country.
middle_east_141: President Obama is seeking authorization from Congress for a military strike against Syria in response to the use of chemical weapons. Secretary of State John Kerry and other officials have made the case for intervention, but some lawmakers remain unconvinced. The resolution authorizing the use of force has been introduced in the Senate and a vote is expected next week. The administration is facing opposition from both Republicans and Democrats, with some questioning the wisdom of military intervention and others expressing concerns about the potential consequences. The President has promised to make the case to the American people in a national address on Tuesday.
elections_165: Bernie Sanders has won the Oregon primary, while Hillary Clinton has narrowly won the Kentucky primary. Sanders has called for changes to the Democratic Party's primary system, citing the use of superdelegates as unfair. Clinton has a significant lead in the delegate count, but Sanders is refusing to drop out of the race. Sanders won Oregon with 53% of the vote, while Clinton won Kentucky with 46.8% of the vote. The close race in Kentucky and Sanders' victory in Oregon suggest that the Democratic primary is far from over.
federal_budget_725: President Obama expressed hope for a resolution to the budget and debt crisis, while House Republicans offered a proposal to raise the debt limit for six weeks. The administration warned that the government could run out of money to pay its bills by Thursday, and negotiations continue to address the shutdown and debt ceiling. Some Senate Republicans are growing impatient with the GOP-led House, and the White House admitted progress in talks. Meanwhile, President Obama's approval ratings have improved, and he urged Congress to pass a budget that reflects the country's priorities.
impeachment_428: Sen. Rand Paul attempted to force Chief Justice John Roberts to read a question naming the anonymous whistleblower in the impeachment trial, but Roberts refused. immigration_274: President Obama has been pushing for immigration reform and has expressed optimism that Congress will have a bill ready next month. elections_149: Mitt Romney has faced criticism for his comments at a private fundraiser, where he stated that 47% of the population is dependent on government and will vote for President Obama. fiscal_cliff_792: The fiscal cliff crisis was averted as Congress passed a last-minute deal that raised taxes on the wealthy and delayed automatic spending cuts. The agreement, reached by Vice President Joe Biden and Senate leaders, included a mix of tax increases and spending cuts, and was passed by the Senate in the early hours of the new year. The deal raised taxes on income over $450,000 and extended unemployment benefits, but did not include entitlement reform or other Democratic priorities. The agreement was met with criticism from both sides, with some Democrats feeling that the party had given away too much and Republicans arguing that the deal did not do enough to address the nation's deficit.
elections_560: As Hurricane Sandy bears down on the East Coast, the presidential campaign is facing a period of heightened uncertainty. Polls show a tight race between President Barack Obama and Mitt Romney, with Obama leading in some surveys and Romney ahead in others. The storm has forced campaign cancellations and may impact early voting and the candidates' ability to communicate with voters. The outcome of the election may depend on the candidates' responses to the storm and how they are perceived by the public.
free_speech_558: CNN has sued the Trump administration for revoking the press pass of their correspondent, Jim Acosta, claiming it violates his First and Fifth Amendment rights. Other news organizations are supporting CNN's lawsuit. The White House has dismissed the lawsuit as "grandstanding" and argues that Acosta was punished for not giving up the microphone during a press conference. The case will be heard in court on Wednesday.
elections_623: Florida's elections are in chaos as recounts are underway for the governor and Senate races. Rick Scott and Bill Nelson are locked in a tight race, with Scott leading by 12,500 votes. The recount has been marred by controversy, with accusations of fraud and irregularities. President Trump has weighed in, calling for an end to the recount and claiming that the election is "infected." The Republican Party has also filed lawsuits against the Broward County supervisor of elections, accusing her of incompetence and gross mismanagement. Meanwhile, the race for governor is also heading for a recount, with Ron DeSantis leading Andrew Gillum by 33,000 votes.
impeachment_706: President Trump's impeachment trial has concluded, with the Senate voting to acquit him on both articles of impeachment. The first article, abuse of power, was voted down with a vote of 52-48, and the second article, obstruction of Congress, was voted down with a vote of 53-47. The impeachment process has been highly partisan, with Democrats arguing that Trump abused his power by pressuring Ukraine to investigate his political rival Joe Biden, and Republicans arguing that the impeachment is a political witch hunt. The acquittal is likely to be a blow to Democrats, who had hoped to remove Trump from office before the 2020 election. The impeachment trial has highlighted the deep divisions within the US political system, with many Americans strongly opposed to Trump's actions and others strongly supporting him.
europe_339: The UK's decision to leave the EU has triggered a wave of political and economic fallout. Prominent Leave campaigners have backtracked on promises of extra funds for the NHS, and the EU has urged the UK to trigger Article 50 to begin the exit process. Global leaders have expressed concerns about the impact of Brexit on the EU and the world economy. In the UK, the Labour Party is facing a leadership crisis after several high-ranking members resigned in protest of Jeremy Corbyn's failure to prevent the Brexit vote. The pound and global stock markets have been affected by the uncertainty, with the Treasury promising to provide reassurance on financial stability.
immigration_536: The Senate Judiciary Committee has begun debating an immigration reform bill, with a focus on border security. The bill's authors, a group of Republicans and Democrats, are facing opposition from both sides of the aisle, with some seeking to strengthen border security provisions and others pushing for a more comprehensive approach. The committee has rejected several amendments, including one that would have tripled the size of the Border Patrol and another that would have required control of the U.S.-Mexico border for six months before anyone could seek legal status. The bill's authors are working to hold together their coalition and defeat amendments that could strike at the bill's core provisions.
immigration_261: President Trump has signed an executive order halting immigration from seven predominantly Muslim countries for 90 days and suspending the admission of refugees for 120 days. The order has been met with widespread protests and legal challenges, with critics arguing that it is discriminatory and unconstitutional. Tech companies such as Google, Microsoft, and Apple have denounced the order, and some have vowed to continue to hire and support immigrants and refugees. The order has also sparked international backlash, with thousands protesting in cities around the world.
us_senate_58: The US government has reopened after a three-day shutdown, with a short-term funding bill passed by Congress and signed by President Trump. The agreement allows for a debate on immigration and other issues, with Democrats accepting a promise from Republicans for a bipartisan discussion. The shutdown ended with a vote of 81-18 in the Senate and 266-150 in the House of Representatives. The funding bill will keep the government open until February 8, and lawmakers are still working on a long-term solution for immigration and other issues.
supreme_court_401: The Senate Judiciary Committee is holding a confirmation hearing for Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump's nominee for the Supreme Court. The hearing has been contentious, with protesters disrupting the proceedings and Democrats questioning Kavanaugh's views on issues such as abortion and executive power. Kavanaugh has declined to comment on Trump's criticism of the judiciary and has refused to pledge to recuse himself from any cases involving the president. Democrats are concerned that Kavanaugh could be a rubber stamp for Trump and protect him from lawsuits and investigations.
